key_points: REvil, a ransomware group known for hacking the U.S. Colonial Pipeline, was itself hacked and deactivated by a multinational cyber operation.
The operation involved the FBI and investigative arms from multiple countries, alongside the U.S. Cyber Command.
REvil was reportedly hacked using a similar technique they employed to compromise targets, exploiting a loophole in the ransomware's backup system.
A leader of REvil, known as 0_neday, acknowledged the server compromise in an internet forum post.
REvil's main spokesperson, known as Unknown, disappeared from the internet in July.
The shutdown maneuver involved law enforcement agencies accessing and disabling REvil's servers from the inside.
Oleg Skulkin, from the Russian security company Group-IB, commented on the irony of REvil's tactics being used against them.
The Colonial Pipeline hack by REvil and DarkSide caused significant fuel shortages and led to a state of emergency being declared across 17 states.
Following the pipeline hack, REvil attacked software management company Kaseya, demanding a large ransom.
The U.S. government has ramped up efforts to treat ransomware attacks on critical infrastructure as national security threats.
spokespersons: Oleg Skulkin (Official, Russian security company Group-IB)
